conclusion: Understand the processes involved in the Stirling cycle.
Stirling cycle consists of two isothermal and two isochoric processes.
Isothermal processes occur at constant temperature.
Isochoric processes occur at constant volume.
During isothermal processes, internal energy does not change.
During isochoric processes, change in internal energy is related to temperature change.
Transition from D to A is an isochoric process.
Determine if temperature increases or decreases from D to A.
In Stirling cycle, transition from D to A is typically a heating process.
Heating process from D to A causes temperature to increase.
Increase in temperature leads to increase in internal energy.
Increase in internal energy corresponds to increase in average kinetic energy.
Average kinetic energy of gas molecules increases from D to A.
